questions.text: Diseases that follow seasonal trend are?

options.label: A
options.text: Varicella

options.label: B
options.text: Cerebro-spinal meningitis

options.label: C
options.text: Rubella

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.correct_answer: D. All of the above
questions.explanation:
Cyclical trends

Seasonal trends

They occur in cycles spread over short periods of time.

Cycles are associated with seasons.

Examples:

  • Measles: every 2-3 years.
  • Rubella: every 6-9 years.
  • Influenza: every 7-10 years.

Examples:

  • Measles.
  • Varicella.
  • Cerebro-spinal meningitis.
  • Upper respiratory tract infections.
  • Malaria.
  • Sunstroke.
  • Hay fever.
  • Snakebite.
  • Rubella

questions.text: What is an ecological fallacy or an ecological bias?

options.label: A
options.text: Associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level.

options.label: B
options.text: Associations observed at an individual level may not hold true at the group level.

options.label: C
options.text: Associations observed at a group level will apply to individual levels.

options.label: D
options.text: Associations at the group level and individual levels are opposite to each other.

questions.correct_answer: A. Associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level.

questions.text: Among the following statements, which is true regarding ecological study designs?

options.label: A
options.text: It is expensive

options.label: B
options.text: Analysis at a population level

options.label: C
options.text: Associations observed at the group level always hold true at the individual level

options.label: D
options.text: Complex study model

questions.correct_answer: B. Analysis at a population level
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Definition
  • It analyses associations between variables at the group or population level by using secondary data.

Strengths
  • Simple and cost-effective.
  • It can suggest potential cause-effect relationships.
  • Useful for studying large populations and trends over time.

Limitations
  • Ecological Fallacy: Associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level.

Examples
  • Study correlating average dietary fat consumption with breast cancer incidence across 20 developed countries.

questions.text: Which of the following studies takes repeated observations from a population via follow-ups?

options.label: A
options.text: Cross-sectional

options.label: B
options.text: Longitudinal

options.label: C
options.text: Both

options.label: D
options.text: None

questions.correct_answer: B. Longitudinal
questions.explanation:
Longitudinal studies

Cross-sectional studies

Observations are repeated using follow-ups in a population.

Observations are done only once in the population.

They are carried over a long period of time (minimum one year).

They are carried over a given point/period of time.

It helps to discover the occurrence of new cases (Incidence rate).

It helps to discover the existence of both old and new cases (Prevalence rate).

It helps to study the natural history of the disease and the risk factors.

They do not help to study the natural history of the disease and the risk factors.

It is time-consuming, difficult, and costly.

It is not time-consuming, not difficult, and cheap.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding cross-sectional study are true except?

options.label: A
options.text: Observations are done only once

options.label: B
options.text: This is cheap and not time-consuming

options.label: C
options.text: Does help to study the natural history of disease

options.label: D
options.text: Carried over a given point of time or period of time

questions.correct_answer: C. Does help to study the natural history of disease

questions.text: In a population of 1000 individuals, 200 develop oral cancers over a 10-year period. Among the total population, 100 are regular tobacco users, from which 60 developed oral cancers. Calculate the Population Attributable Risk (PAR) of oral cancers due to tobacco use in this population.
questions.explanation:
Tobacco user

No Tobacco

Total

Disease Present

60

140

200

Disease Absent

40

760

800

Total

100

900

1000

Odds ratio (OR) = (odds of exposure among cases) / (odds of exposure among controls)

Relative Risk (RR) = Incidence (exposed) / Incidence (unexposed)

 

Attributable Risk (AR) = Incidence (unexposed) - Incidence (exposed) / Incidence (unexposed)

Population Attributable Risk (PAR) = Incidence (total) - Incidence (unexposed) / Incidence (total)

questions.text: In a study of 500 children, 200 were vaccinated against measles, and 300 were not. Out of the 200 vaccinated children, 10 developed measles. Among the 300 unvaccinated children, 90 developed measles. Calculate the attributable risk of developing measles due to lack of vaccination.
questions.explanation:
Vaccinated

Not Vaccinated

Total

Disease Present

10

90

100

Disease Absent

190

210

400

Total

200

300

500

questions.text: A study was conducted over 10 years to evaluate the risk of mesothelioma among people working in the ship-based industry. The study included 200 workers exposed to asbestos and 300 workers not exposed to asbestos. Among those exposed, 40 developed mesothelioma and died at the terminal stage, while only 5 of the unexposed group developed mesothelioma and died. What is the relative risk of developing mesothelioma and dying for workers exposed to asbestos compared to those not exposed?
questions.explanation:
Exposed to Asbestos

Not Exposed to Asbestos

Total

Mesothelioma

(Disease Present)

40

5

45

No Mesothelioma

(Disease Absent)

160

295

455

Total

200

300

500

questions.text: A community health department has noted rising cirrhosis cases. To investigate if alcohol consumption is a risk factor, what study design should health workers use?

options.label: A
options.text: Cross-Sectional Study

options.label: B
options.text: Case-Control Study

options.label: C
options.text: Cohort Study

options.label: D
options.text: Randomised Controlled Trial

questions.correct_answer: C. Cohort Study

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the cross-product ratio?

options.label: A
options.text: It is also known as the incidence rate.

options.label: B
options.text: It measures the relative risk in cohort studies.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides an estimation of disease risk associated with exposure.

options.label: D
options.text: A value of > 1 indicates an inverse association or protective factor

questions.correct_answer: C. It provides an estimation of disease risk associated with exposure.
questions.explanation:
OR > 1

Positive association or possible risk factor

OR = 1

No association

OR < 1

Negative association, inverse association, or protective factor

questions.text: Below is a graphical representation of the odds ratio (OR) and risk ratio (RR) for various incidence rates. Which of the following is false?

options.label: A
options.text: As RR increases, OR increases at a higher rate for all incidence rates

options.label: B
options.text: OR always underestimates the RR

options.label: C
options.text: The yellow line represents a much larger OR than the RR

options.label: D
options.text: The pink line represents a lower incidence rate.

questions.correct_answer: B. OR always underestimates the RR

questions.text: To investigate the association between high cholesterol levels and the development of hypertension, researchers collected data from 100 patients with hypertension and 210 patients without disease. 60 patients had high cholesterol levels in the hypertensive group, while 30 patients had high cholesterol levels in the non-hypertensive group. What are the odds of having high cholesterol levels in hypertensive patients?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factor/Exposure

High cholesterol

Low cholesterol

Hypertension

60 (a)

40 (b)

No hypertension

30 (c)

180 (d)

questions.text: A research team conducts a study to investigate the association between smoking and bladder cancer. They select a group of patients with and without bladder cancer and compare their smoking history. Which of the following best describes the significance of the study in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for the determination of the incidence of bladder cancer among smokers and non-smokers.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to establish a temporal relationship between smoking and bladder cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a cost-effective and efficient way to study the association between smoking and bladder cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used to follow patients over time to observe the development of bladder cancer.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a cost-effective and efficient way to study the association between smoking and bladder cancer.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Case-Control Study

Cohort Study

Definition

Compares individuals with a disease (cases) to those without (controls)

Follows a group (cohort) over time to see who develops the disease.

Study Design

Retrospective or prospective.

Prospective (or retrospective in some designs).

Data Collection

Usually relies on existing records or interviews

Collects data over time, often with direct measurements.

Population

Starts with disease status (cases vs. controls)

Starts with exposure status (exposed vs. unexposed).

Advantages

- Quick and inexpensive.

- Useful for rare diseases.

- Can study multiple exposures.

- Can establish temporal relationships.

- Useful for studying multiple outcomes.

- Less bias in exposure measurement

Disadvantages

- Prone to recall bias.

- Cannot directly measure incidence.

- Selection bias may occur.

- Time-consuming and expensive.

- Requires large sample sizes.

- Loss to follow-up can affect results.

questions.text: To investigate the relationship between hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and breast cancer, researchers conducted a study where they selected patients with breast cancer from an ongoing cohort study and compared HRT usage among cancer-free women from the same cohort. What type of study design does this scenario indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Cohort study

options.label: B
options.text: Case-control study

options.label: C
options.text: Nested case-control study

options.label: D
options.text: Cross-sectional study

questions.correct_answer: C. Nested case-control study

questions.text: The following are some steps taken to investigate an epidemic. Arrange the steps in the correct sequence. Verification of the diagnosis. Define the population at risk. Data analysis. Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic. Evaluation of ecological factors. Testing of hypothesis.
questions.explanation:
Steps

Salient points

1

Verification of diagnosis
  • Most important step
  • Examination of a sample of cases and verify the diagnosis
  • To avoid a spurious diagnosis based on signs and symptoms.

2

Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic
  • Compare data collected with the previous year's data.
  • Epidemic:
    • Occurrence > 2 S.D.
    • The cases occur at over 80% of the expected frequency.

3

Defining the population at risk
  • Obtain a map of the area affected.
  • A house-to-house survey is done to find the entire population at risk.

4

Rapid search for all cases and their characteristics
  • Medical survey.
  • Epidemiological case sheet.

5

Data analysis
  • Done in terms of Time, Place and person
  • Try to identify the type of epidemic by drawing the epidemic curve.

6

Formulation of hypothesis
  • It contains information about the agent, host, environment, modes of transmission, etc.
  • Formulation of a hypothesis is the work of descriptive epidemiology.

7

Testing of hypothesis
  • First step: Case-control study.
  • Second step: Plan a cohort study to compare the attack rates in exposed vs non-exposed groups.

8

Evaluation of ecological factors
  • Effect of humidity.
  • Effect of sanitary conditions.
  • Effect of water supply.

9

Further investigation of the population at risk
  • Keep looking for any other population that is at risk.

10

Writing the report
  • To provide a strategy at the end.
  • Prevent future occurrences.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about secular trends?

options.label: A
options.text: A roadside accident is a good example.

options.label: B
options.text: It is due to environmental factors.

options.label: C
options.text: This is due to the commonly occurring variation in herd immunity.

options.label: D
options.text: Consistent change in a particular direction over a period of time.

questions.correct_answer: D. Consistent change in a particular direction over a period of time.

questions.text: Study designs are used for which of the following purposes?

options.label: A
options.text: Formulating a hypothesis

options.label: B
options.text: Testing a hypothesis

options.label: C
options.text: Confirming a hypothesis

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.correct_answer: D. All of the above
questions.explanation:
Formulation of a hypothesis

 A hypothesis is formulated when no knowledge about a new disease exists. Descriptive epidemiology, which focuses on time, place, and person, helps in these cases. For instance, early in the COVID-19 outbreak, it was hypothesised as a type of pneumonia.

Testing a hypothesis

 Testing addresses how and why a disease occurs and is a key aspect of Analytical epidemiology. Eg; comparing individuals with COVID-19 to those without it to understand the disease better.

Confirmation of a hypothesis

 The disease is confirmed through Experimental or Interventional epidemiology. Eg; once COVID-19 was confirmed, vaccines and treatments were developed

questions.text: What is the image given below used for?

options.label: A
options.text: Local distribution of a disease

options.label: B
options.text: Rural-urban variation

options.label: C
options.text: National variation

options.label: D
options.text: Migration studies

questions.correct_answer: A. Local distribution of a disease
questions.explanation:
International variation

Comparisons of disease incidence, prevalence, and patterns between different countries.

National variation

Study disease patterns within a single country, observing differences across regions or states.

Rural-urban variation

Comparisons of disease incidence and prevalence between rural and urban areas within a country.

Local distribution

Detailed examination of disease patterns within small areas, such as specific neighbourhoods or districts.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes ‘person distribution’ in descriptive epidemiology?

options.label: A
options.text: The distribution of people across an area under study.

options.label: B
options.text: The population's disease analysis is based on the characteristics of the people who develop them.

options.label: C
options.text: Distribution of human resources to various tasks of the study.

options.label: D
options.text: Distribution of residents within different neighbourhoods or urban areas.

questions.correct_answer: B. The population's disease analysis is based on the characteristics of the people who develop them.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes a propagated epidemic?

options.label: A
options.text: It is typically caused by a single brief and simultaneous exposure to a common source.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows an epidemic curve with one peak that rises and falls rapidly with no secondary waves.

options.label: C
options.text: Transmission occurs gradually through person-to-person transmission, rising and tailing off in the epidemic curve.

options.label: D
options.text: A propagated epidemic can only occur if the disease has a short incubation period.

questions.correct_answer: C. Transmission occurs gradually through person-to-person transmission, rising and tailing off in the epidemic curve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a common source epidemic with a single exposure?

options.label: A
options.text: The epidemic curve shows a rapid increase and decrease in cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Cases are spread across multiple incubation periods of the disease.

options.label: C
options.text: The epidemic often appears as an explosive outbreak with cases clustered quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: Most cases occur within a single incubation period of the disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. Cases are spread across multiple incubation periods of the disease.
questions.explanation:
Properties

Point source or single exposure epidemic

Continuous or repeated exposure

Intermittent exposure

Exposure Timing

Brief and simultaneous

Prolonged, continuous, repeated, or intermittent

Intermittent

Incubation Period

All cases develop within one incubation period (Option D)

Cases develop over multiple incubation periods (Option B)

Unrelated to the incubation period

Epidemic Curve

Single peak; rises and falls rapidly (Option A)

Extended or irregular curve

Multiple peaks

Explosiveness

Explosive with rapid clustering of cases (Option C)

No explosive rise in cases

-

Secondary waves

None

May continue without clear secondary waves

-

Disease Agent Source

Often due to a single infectious agent or contaminant

Prolonged or repeated exposure to an infectious agent or contaminant

-

Examples
  • Food poisoning.
  • Industrial contamination (e.g., Bhopal gas tragedy, Minamata disease)
  • Contaminated water source.
  • Continuous exposure to pollutants.
  • Prolonged outbreaks (Legionnaires disease)
  • Contaminated food or tinned product which is sold over a period of time.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly distinguishes between hyperendemic and holoendemic diseases with appropriate examples?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperendemic- Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa Holoendemic- Common cold worldwide

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperendemic- Influenza during winter in temperate regions Holoendemic- Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperendemic- Tuberculosis in urban areas Holoendemic- Seasonal influenza

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperendemic- Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa Holoendemic- Influenza during winter in temperate regions

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyperendemic- Influenza during winter in temperate regions Holoendemic- Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa

questions.text: Match the following terms related to disease distribution with their appropriate examples: Term Example i) Endemic a) A sudden surge in influenza cases during the winter months. ii) Epidemic b) The persistent occurrence of malaria in certain regions of Africa. iii) Pandemic c) Isolated instances of tetanus infection with no discernible pattern. iv) Sporadic d) The global spread of COVID-19 affecting multiple continents.

options.label: A
options.text: i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c

options.label: B
options.text: i-a, ii-b, iii-d, iv-c

options.label: C
options.text: i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b

options.label: D
options.text: i-d, ii-c, iii-a, iv-b

questions.correct_answer: A. i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c
questions.explanation:
Term

Definition

Examples

Epidemic
  • Occurrence of disease clearly in excess of normal expectancy (Mean + 2SD or >80% expected frequency).
  • Occurrence of even a single case of a previously eliminated disease.
  • Occurrence of a single case of an exotic disease.

Seasonal influenza outbreaks during winter months.

Endemic
  • Constant presence of a disease within a specific population.
  • Epidemiologically linked cases in terms of time, place, or person.

Malaria in Africa, TB in India

 

Pandemic
  • Global spread of a disease.
  • Defined as an epidemic in a large population.
  • Requires crossing 2 continents and 2 WHO-specific regions.

HIV/AIDS, COVID-19.

Sporadic
  • They occur randomly and unpredictably, without any discernible pattern in time, location, or individual.
  • There's no epidemiological link between the cases.

Tetanus

questions.text: A public health researcher is investigating the association between air pollution and asthma in children. The researcher collects data from a population over several years, documenting the levels of air pollution and the incidence of new asthma cases. Which of the following best describes the study design?

options.label: A
options.text: Interventional study

options.label: B
options.text: Analytical Study - Cohort

options.label: C
options.text: Descriptive Study

options.label: D
options.text: Analytical Study - Case Control

questions.correct_answer: B. Analytical Study - Cohort
questions.explanation:
OBSERVATIONAL STUDIES

EXPERIMENTAL/INTERVENTIONAL STUDIES

Descriptive

Analytical

Case reports

Ecological studies

Randomised controlled trials

Case series

Case-control studies

Field trials

Cohort studies

Community trials

Cross-sectional studies

questions.text: What is the first step in determining a descriptive study design?

options.label: A
options.text: Defining the disease under study

options.label: B
options.text: Defining the population of interest

options.label: C
options.text: Describe the disease in terms of time, place, and person

options.label: D
options.text: Formulate a hypothesis

questions.correct_answer: B. Defining the population of interest
questions.explanation:
Step 1

Defining the population of interest is the first step in descriptive study design, i.e. the socio-demographic profiling of the population. For a population to be a part of a descriptive study design, it has to be:

  • Stable.
  • No migration
  • Community participation: A sample of the population should represent the entire population

Step 2

Define the disease under study (Option A)

Step 3

Describe the disease in terms of time, place, and person (Option C)

Step 4

Measure the disease, i.e. health indicators such as mortality, morbidity and disability rates.

Step 5

Compare with known indices.

Step 6

Formulate a hypothesis (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding descriptive epidemiology?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a study of the distribution of disease w.r.t. time, place, and person

options.label: B
options.text: It tests a hypothesis

options.label: C
options.text: It is the first phase of epidemiological investigation

options.label: D
options.text: Descriptive epidemiology does not involve a comparison group

questions.correct_answer: B. It tests a hypothesis

questions.text: A researcher is interested in examining the prevalence of hypertension among adults in a city and wants to identify any associated risk factors such as age, diet, and physical activity at a single time. The researcher collects data from a large sample of adults in the city. Which type of study design is the researcher using in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Cohort study

options.label: B
options.text: Cross-sectional study

options.label: C
options.text: Case-control study

options.label: D
options.text: Ecological study

questions.correct_answer: B. Cross-sectional study

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding experimental studies is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Interventional study can confirm/discard a hypothesis

options.label: B
options.text: Healthy individuals are a unit of study in randomised clinical trials

options.label: C
options.text: Cost and ethical concerns are seen in experimental studies

options.label: D
options.text: Experimental studies often include control groups to compare the effects of the intervention.

questions.correct_answer: B. Healthy individuals are a unit of study in randomised clinical trials
questions.explanation:
Experimental study

Unit of study

RCT

Diseased individuals

Field trials (e.g. Vaccine trials)

Healthy Individuals

Advantages

Disadvantages
  • Provides evidence for the direct effect of an intervention and its outcome. Hence, a disease can be confirmed using Experimental or Interventional epidemiology (Option A).
  • For example, vaccines and drug manufacturing took place after the confirmation of the COVID-19 virus.
  • Cost: Experimental studies, especially large-scale RCTs, can be expensive to conduct (Option C).

 
  • Evaluate the efficacy of new drugs, vaccines, and therapies and compare between two interventional groups.
  • Ethical concerns: Ethical considerations often pose limitations on experimental studies (Option C).

questions.text: Match column A's types of studies with the appropriate option in column B. COLUMN A COLUMN B a) Cross-sectional i) Testing of hypothesis b) Ecological ii) Prevalence c) Descriptive study iii) First Phase in Epidemiology d) Analytical study iv) Population as the unit of study

options.label: A
options.text: a-ii, b-iv, c- iii, d-i

options.label: B
options.text: a-i, b-ii, c- iv, d-iii

options.label: C
options.text: a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii

options.label: D
options.text: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

questions.correct_answer: A. a-ii, b-iv, c- iii, d-i

questions.text: In community medicine research, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Case series are used to establish causality between an exposure and an outcome.

options.label: B
options.text: Case reports are descriptive studies, while case series are analytical studies

options.label: C
options.text: Case series is formed by compiling reports of cases with diverse characteristics

options.label: D
options.text: Case series do not include a comparison group

questions.correct_answer: D. Case series do not include a comparison group
questions.explanation:
Case report

Case Series

Includes a single individual with unique or unusual findings

Aggregation or collection of case reports that have a similar finding (Option C)

They are both a type of descriptive study and do not require a comparison group (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of analytical study?

options.label: A
options.text: The subject of interest is the population

options.label: B
options.text: The subject of interest is an individual within the population

options.label: C
options.text: Helps in formulating a hypothesis

options.label: D
options.text: No comparison group is present

questions.correct_answer: B. The subject of interest is an individual within the population
questions.explanation:
Descriptive Study

Analytical study

The subject of interest is population (Option A)

The subject of interest is an individual within the  population (Option B), except in ecological study where the unit is population

A comparison group is not present (Option D)

A comparison group is present

Helps in formulating a hypothesis (Option C)

Helps is testing a hypothesis

E.g. Case report, case series

E.g. Cohort studies and case-control studies.
